# Helsingin Kaupunginvaltuuston Kokouspöytäkirja 22.6.2022

## Esityslistan Yhteenveto
§183-184: Vuoden 2021 arviointikertomus ja tilintarkastuskertomus sekä vastuuvapaus vuodelta 2021 ja Helsingin kaupungin vuoden 2021 tilinpäätöksen hyväksyminen - Kaupungin vuoden 2021 tilinpäätöstä käsiteltiin, jossa todettiin pandemian vaikutukset ja talouden vakaus. Valtuutetut toivat esiin huolenaiheita, kuten työvoimapulan, palkanmaksuongelmat ja investointien kestävyyden.
§188: Tilojen vuokraaminen Kiinteistö Oy Helsingin Toimitiloilta englantilaisen koulun käyttöön - Keskusteltiin tilojen vuokraamisesta englantilaiselle koululle, erityisesti liito-oravien elinalueiden huomioon ottamisesta.
§191: Haagan Steniuksenkentän alueen asemakaavan muuttaminen (nro 12697) - Keskusteltiin asemakaavan muutoksesta, jossa valtuutetut toivat esiin huolenaiheita liittyen asukkaiden kuulemiseen, liikuntamahdollisuuksiin ja alueen luonteeseen.
§192: Valtuutettu Suldaan Said Ahmedin aloite palestiinalaisalueiden laittomasta miehityksestä ja Helsingin kaupungin hankinnoista - Keskusteltiin aloitteesta, joka koskee palestiinalaisalueiden laittoman miehityksen huomioimista kaupungin hankinnoissa. Valtuutetut toivat esiin näkemyksiä ulkopolitiikasta, ihmisoikeuksista ja hankintalain tulkinnasta.

## Yksityiskohtainen Keskustelu

### §183-184: Vuoden 2021 arviointikertomus ja tilintarkastuskertomus sekä vastuuvapaus vuodelta 2021 ja Helsingin kaupungin vuoden 2021 tilinpäätöksen hyväksyminen
**Pormestari Juhana Vartiainen**: Korosti pandemian vaikutuksia ja kaupungin talouden hallintaa, sekä Venäjän hyökkäyksen vaikutuksia. Hän kiitti henkilöstöä ja ehdotti kulttuuri- ja liikuntaseteliä henkilöstölle. Hän korosti kasvun merkitystä ja edunvalvontaa valtion suuntaan.
**Tarkastuslautakunnan puheenjohtaja Nuutti Hyttinen**: Esitteli arviointikertomuksen havaintoja ja suosituksia eri toimialoille, kuten Apotin puutteet, koronapandemiasta palautumisen seuranta, ikääntyneiden kotihoidon haasteet, mielenterveyskuntoutujien palvelut ja oppilaiden poissaolotietojen seuranta. Hän toi esiin myös Hekan vuokralaisdemokratian puutteita.
**Valtuutettu Jenni Pajunen **: Korosti hintojen nousun vaikutuksia helsinkiläisiin ja energiapolitiikan haasteita. Hän painotti, että kaupunki ei saa omilla päätöksillään kasvattaa kuluttajien taakkaa. Hän toi esiin oppimiserojen kasvun ja englanninkielisen opetuksen tarpeen. Hän kannatti kulttuuri- ja liikuntaseteliä henkilöstölle ja tilinpäätöksen hyväksymistä.
**Valtuutettu Shawn Huff **: Korosti ilmastotavoitteiden aikaistamista ja luonnon huomioon ottamista kaupunkisuunnittelussa. Hän toi esiin huolen joukkoliikenteen käytön vähenemisestä ja lasten ja nuorten hyvinvoinnin tärkeyttä. Hän korosti työvoimapulaa varhaiskasvatuksessa ja hoitoalalla ja kannatti tilinpäätöksen hyväksymistä.
**Valtuutettu Hilkka Ahde **: Kiitti kaupungin henkilöstöä ja totesi kaupungin talouden olevan vakaalla pohjalla. Hän toi esiin työvoiman saatavuuden ongelmat lastensuojelussa ja kotihoidossa sekä terveysasemien jonot. Hän korosti palkanmaksuongelmia ja vaati niiden korjaamista.
**Ledamoten Mia Haglund **: Muistutti opettajien ahdingosta koronakriisin ja koulutusleikkausten keskellä. Hän totesi, että kaupungin talous selvisi koronakriisissä hyvin, ja kaupungin tilikauden tulos oli 350 miljoonaa euroa. Hän korosti varhaiskasvatuksen ja koulutuksen merkitystä ja budjetointijärjestelmän kriisinkestävyyttä.
**Valtuutettu Mari Rantanen **: Kuvaili kaupungin toimintaympäristöä ennustamattomaksi ja toi esiin pandemian epätasapuoliset vaikutukset helsinkiläisten arkeen. Hän huomautti kaupunkikonsernin suuresta lainakannasta ja korkojen nousun vaikutuksista. Hän esitti selvityksen tekemistä Helsingistä poispäin kohdistuvan muuttoliikkeen syistä.
**Ledamoten Marcus Rantala **: Totesi Helsingin selviytyneen taloudellisesti hyvin pandemian aikana. Hän korosti työperäisen maahanmuuton merkitystä ja ruotsinkielisen kotihoidon kriisiä. Hän toi esiin huolen nuorten hyvinvoinnista ja kannatti tilinpäätöksen hyväksymistä.
**Valtuutettu Kimmo Niemelä **: Totesi, että olemme uuden äärellä sekä inhimillisesti että taloudellisesti. Hän korosti kaupungin hyvää taloudellista pohjaa huolimatta pandemian vaikutuksista. Hän toi esiin asukasmäärän kasvun hidastumisen ja muuttoliikkeen muuttumisen tappiolliseksi. Hän korosti kansainvälisen kilpailukyvyn ja houkuttelevuuden tärkeyttä.
**Valtuutettu Terhi Peltokorpi **: Totesi, että Helsinki on selviytynyt hyvin ja on edelleen kasvava kaupunki. Hän toi esiin, että vain puolet valtuuston sitovista toiminnan tavoitteista toteutui. Hän korosti palkanmaksun ongelmia ja hyvinvointi- ja terveyserojen kaventamisen tärkeyttä.
**Valtuutettu Mika Ebeling **: Totesi, että Helsingin tilikauden tulos oli suhteutettuna toteutuneeseen investointitasoon jonkin verran keskimääräistä heikompi. Hän toi esiin merkittäviä epäonnistumisia vanhusväestön asioiden hoitamisessa. Hän korosti, että Helsingin pitää tulevina vuosina, jotka ovat vaikeita vuosia, pitää huolta niistä, jotka muuten eivät pärjää.
**Valtuutettu Pia Pakarinen **: Kiinnitti huomiota siihen, miten vähän kaupungissa panostetaan elinkeinotoimintaan. Hän korosti innovaatiorahaston merkitystä.
**Valtuutettu Otto Meri **: Totesi, että Helsingin taloudella pyyhkii hyvin ja taloutta hoidettu vastuullisesti. Hän toi esiin vuosikatteen ja maanmyyntitulojen merkityksen investointien rahoituksen näkökulmasta. Hän korosti sote-uudistuksen vaikutuksia kaupungin verokertymään ja investointikykyyn.
**Valtuutettu Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Totesi, että arviointikertomus on jälleen erittäin hyvin laadittu, ja se kiinnittää huomiota moniin tärkeisiin asioihin tätä ja seuraavaa vuotta varten. Hän toi esiin kotihoidon liian pienen henkilöstömäärän.
**Valtuutettu Titta Hiltunen **: Totesi, että mielenterveyskuntoutujan polku sairaalahoidosta asumiseen on monin paikoin tosi karua luettavaa. Ensimmäinen ongelma on se, että asumispalveluun pääsyä voi joutua jonottamaan vuosia.
**Valtuutettu Maarit Vierunen **: Totesi, että näiden poikkeuksellisten aikojen keskellä tilinpäätöksenkin luvut näyttävät ymmärrettävästi varsin poikkeuksellisilta. Hän korosti, että viisas, tulevaisuuteen varautuva taloudenpito on loppujen lopuksi jokaisen helsinkiläisen tuki ja turva.
**Valtuutettu Mia Nygård-Peltola **: Totesi, että kaupunkistrategian keskeinen teema on kasvu. Hän korosti verotusratkaisujen merkitystä vetovoima- ja houkuttelevuustekijänä.
**Valtuutettu Amanda Pasanen **: Totesi, että kaupunkien kestävä kasvu on ehkä yksi tämän sukupolven isoimmista haasteista. Hän kannusti kaikkia allekirjoittamaan varavaltuutettu Saana Rossin mahtavan valtuustoaloitteen järjestelmässä, jossa esitetään sitä, että luonnonkasveja lisättäisiin kaupunkiympäristössä.

### §188: Tilojen vuokraaminen Kiinteistö Oy Helsingin Toimitiloilta englantilaisen koulun käyttöön
**Ledamoten Björn Månsson **: Kysyi, pitääkö paikkansa, että alue on liito-oravien ydinalue, ja eikö koululle ole voitu löytää muuta paikkaa.
**Valtuutettu Laura Korpinen **: Esitti päätösehdotuksen hylkäämistä, koska uudisrakennuksen tarpeisiin suunnitellut tontit kuuluvat Riistavuorenpuistoon ja ovat osa laajempaa metsäkokonaisuutta.
**Apulaispormestari Anni Sinnemäki **: Totesi, että paikka on jo kaavoitettu koululle ja liito-oravaa koskevat omat menettelytapansa.
**Valtuutettu Pia Kopra **: Kannatti Riistavuoren metsän säästämistä ja valtuutettu Korpisen hylkäysehdotusta.

### §191: Haagan Steniuksenkentän alueen asemakaavan muuttaminen (nro 12697)
**Valtuutettu Pia Kopra **: Totesi, että asemakaavan muutosehdotus ei noudata Etelä-Haagan kaavoitusperiaatteita ja asukkaita ei ole kuunneltu. Hän esitti, että koko kaavamuutos hylätään.
**Apulaispormestari Paavo Arhinmäki **: Totesi, että Haagan liikuntapuiston myötä liikuntamahdollisuudet ja kenttien määrä tulee merkittävästi lisääntymään, ei vähentymään.
**Ledamoten Björn Månsson **: Kysyi, miten voidaan sivuuttaa lahjoitus nimenomaan urheilukentän perustamisesta.
**Valtuutettu Sami Muttilainen **: Kannatti Haagan puiston säästämistä rakentamiselta.
**Valtuutettu Laura Korpinen **: Kannatti valtuutettu Kopran hylkäysehdotusta ja totesi, että on ikävä tyyli hoitaa tämmöistä asiaa, että tällä lailla hiljaa hivuttamalla muutellaan näitä kaavoja.

### §192: Valtuutettu Suldaan Said Ahmedin aloite palestiinalueiden laittomasta miehityksestä ja Helsingin kaupungin hankinnoista
**Valtuutettu Minja Koskela **: Totesi, että pohja on hyvin maltillinen, ja se on myös omalta osaltani kompromissi. Hän esitti selvityksen tekemistä mahdollisuudesta ulossulkea kaupungin hankinnoista siirtokuntatuotteita hankintalain harkinnanvaraisten poissulkemisperusteiden nojalla ja huomioida ihmisoikeusnäkökulma nykyistä vahvemmin kaikissa hankinnoissa painottaen erityisesti hankintoja, joiden arvo alittaa hankintalain kynnysarvon.
**Valtuutettu Jussi Halla-aho **: Totesi, että harva miehitystilanne on niin nyansoitu ja monitulkintainen kuin Länsirannan miehitys. Hän teki palautusesityksen, jonka sisältö on se, että perusteluteksti palautetaan vastaamaan sitä pohjaa, jonka valmistelija toi meille kaupunginhallitukseen 13.6.
**Apulaispormestari Paavo Arhinmäki **: Totesi, että Länsi-Saharan miehitetyiltä alueilta ei pidä tehdä hankintoja. Krimin niemimaalta miehitetyiltä alueilta ei pidä tehdä hankintoja. Ei myöskään Donbasin alueelta Ukrainasta pidä tehdä hankintoja.
**Valtuutettu Seida Sohrabi **: Totesi, että kaupunginvaltuustossa ei kuulu käsitellä ensisijaisesti sisä- ja ulkopolitiikkaan liittyviä asioita, joita tämä aloite nimenomaan koskettaa. Hän kannatti Halla-ahon palautusehdotusta.
**Valtuutettu Ville Jalovaara **: Pohdiskeli, äänestääkö tyhjää vai äänestääkö pohjan puolesta.
**Valtuutettu Atte Kaleva **: Kannatti valtuutettu Halla-ahon palautusesitystä.
**Valtuutettu Nuutti Hyttinen **: Kannatti myöskin valtuutettu Halla-ahon tekemää palautusehdotusta.
**Valtuutettu Coel Thomas **: Totesi, että Israel suorittaa hidasta, mutta päättäväistä etnistä puhdistusta Palestiinassa. Hän kannatti valtuutettu Koskelan pontta ja vastusti valtuutettu Halla-ahon palautusta.
**Valtuutettu Mika Raatikainen **: Päätti pidättäytyä kokonaan äänestämisestä.
**Valtuutettu Nina Suomalainen **: Kannatti tämän tekstin jatkokäsittelyä, eli en kannata palautusta.
**Valtuutettu Marko Kettunen **: Totesi, että julkisten hankintojen tekeminen on äärimmäisen työlästä vaativaa työtä, ja sen hankaloittaminen lisäehdoilla ei missään tapauksessa ole kaupunkilaisten etu.
**Valtuutettu Mari Rantanen **: Kannatti tätä palautusta.
**Ledamoten Mia Haglund **: Totesi, että tämä aloite ja sen vastaus ei ole kannanotto Israelin valtiota vastaan.
**Ledamoten Thomas Wallgren **: Pitäisi tärkeänä, että valtuuston valmistelussa osataan tehdä tämä ero eikä käytettäisi oikeudellisia arvioita poliittisesti tarkoituksenmukaisesti.

# Helsinki City Council Meeting Minutes from June 15, 2022

## Agenda Overview
§171: **Helsinki City Environmental Report 2021** - The council reviewed the environmental report, discussing emissions, air quality, water protection, biodiversity, and circular economy. The report highlighted both progress and challenges in meeting Helsinki's environmental goals, particularly the carbon neutrality target by 2030.

§172: **Project Plan for the New Building of Pasila Primary School and Kindergarten** - The council discussed the project plan for a new primary school and kindergarten in Pasila to address the growing need for educational facilities in the area. The plan includes consolidating the school and kindergarten into one location and innovative design solutions due to the tight construction site.

§173: **Determining Rental Principles for Apartment Building Plots (Kannelmäki, Kaarela Plots 33130/10, 11, 18 and 19)** - The council discussed the rental principles for apartment building plots in Kannelmäki and Kaarela. A key point of contention was the confidentiality of the property valuation report, leading to a broader discussion about transparency in municipal decision-making.

§175: **Amending the Local Detailed Plan for Damaskuksentie 4 in Toukola (No. 12733)** - The council discussed amending the local detailed plan for Damaskuksentie 4 in Toukola. The discussion focused on balancing the need for new housing with the concerns of residents in established residential areas.

§176: **Amending the Local Detailed Plan for Onnentie 18 in Käpylä (No. 12765)** - The council discussed amending the local detailed plan for Onnentie 18 in Käpylä, involving the conversion of a former school building into residential housing. The discussion centered on the historical significance of the site, the need for housing, and the process of balancing development with community concerns.

§178: **Initiative by Councillor Mari Rantanen on Naming Streets After Mannerheim Cross Knights Born in Helsinki** - The council discussed an initiative to name streets after Mannerheim Cross Knights born in Helsinki. While a decision was made to name a park area instead, the discussion highlighted the importance of honoring historical figures and the process of public commemoration.

§179: **Initiative by Councillor Teija Makkonen for a Football Hall in Tapulikaupunki Sports Park** - The council discussed an initiative for a football hall in Tapulikaupunki Sports Park. The discussion focused on the need for improved winter sports facilities, the cost-effectiveness of different solutions, and the suitability of the proposed location.

## Detailed Discussion

### §171: Helsinki City Environmental Report 2021
**Anni Sinnemäki **: Presented the environmental report, noting that emissions remained at 2020 levels, which is insufficient for meeting reduction targets. She highlighted the increase in district heating emissions and the need for steeper emission reductions, especially in transportation. Sinnemäki also emphasized the importance of climate adaptation measures and the city's commitment to biodiversity.

**Reetta Vanhanen **: Acknowledged both positive and concerning aspects of the report. # Helsingin Kaupunginvaltuuston Kokous 15.6.2022

## Agenda Overview
§1: **Helsingin Kaupungin Ympäristöraportti 2021** - Valtuusto käsitteli ympäristöraporttia, jossa arvioitiin kaupungin ympäristönsuojelua ja ilmastotoimia. Päästöjen vähentämisen haasteet ja toimenpiteet, liikenteen päästöt, luonnon monimuotoisuus sekä kiertotalous olivat keskeisiä teemoja.
§2: **Pasilan Peruskoulun ja Päiväkodin Uudisrakennuksen Hankesuunnitelma** - Valtuusto käsitteli Pasilan peruskoulun ja päiväkodin uudisrakennuksen hankesuunnitelmaa, joka pyrkii vastaamaan alueen kasvavaan tarpeeseen varhaiskasvatuksen ja perusopetuksen tiloista. Suunnitelmassa huomioidaan pedagogiset tarpeet ja tilojen monipuolinen käyttö.
§3: **Vuokrausperiaatteiden Määrittäminen Asuinkerrostalotonteille (Kannelmäki, Kaarela Tontit 33130/10, 11, 18 Ja 19)** - Valtuusto käsitteli vuokrausperiaatteita Kannelmäen ja Kaarelan asuinkerrostalotonteille. Keskustelua herätti kiinteistökonsulttien kanssa tehtyjen salaisten arviosopimusten avoimuus.
§4: **Toukola Damaskuksentie 4:n Asemakaavan Muuttaminen (Nro 12733)** - Valtuusto käsitteli Toukolan Damaskuksentie 4:n asemakaavan muutosta, joka mahdollistaa täydennysrakentamisen pientaloalueen läheisyydessä. Keskustelua herättivät asukkaiden huolet ja täydennysrakentamisen vaikutukset.
§5: **Käpylä Onnentie 18 Asemakaavan Muuttaminen (Nro 12765)** - Valtuusto käsitteli Käpylän Onnentie 18:n asemakaavan muutosta, jossa vanha koulurakennus muutetaan asuinrakennukseksi. Keskustelua herättivät asukkaiden huolet, koulun lahjoitusehdot ja alueen väistötilatarpeet.
§6: **Valtuutettu Mari Rantasen Aloite Katujen Nimeämisestä Helsingissä Syntyneiden Mannerheim-Ristin Ritareiden Mukaan** - Valtuusto käsitteli valtuutettu Mari Rantasen aloitetta katujen nimeämisestä Helsingissä syntyneiden Mannerheim-ristin ritareiden mukaan. Päätettiin nimetä Ratsaspuistossa sijaitseva puistosommitelma Mannerheim-ristin ritareiden aukioksi.
§7: **Valtuutettu Teija Makkosen Aloite Jalkapallohallista Tapulikaupungin Liikuntapuistoon** - Valtuusto käsitteli valtuutettu Teija Makkosen aloitetta jalkapallohallista Tapulikaupungin liikuntapuistoon. Keskustelua herättivät jalkapallon talviolosuhteet, hallin kustannukset ja alueen liikuntapaikkatarpeet.

# Helsinki City Council Meeting Minutes from 18.5.2022

## Agenda Overview
§1: **Changes to the 2022 Budget Due to the Corporatization of Helsinki City Transport (HKL)** - This agenda item addresses the technical adjustments required in the city's 2022 budget following the decision to corporatize HKL's operations. The discussion focuses on the potential impacts on the city's finances and the working conditions of HKL employees.
§2: **AM-Program 2020 Monitoring Report 2022** - This agenda item reviews the progress and challenges in implementing the City's housing and land use program (AM-ohjelma). The report assesses the achievement of housing production targets, affordability, and the impact of the pandemic on housing market trends.
§3: **Myllypuro Karhunkaataja Area Zoning Plan and Zoning Change (No. 12550)** - This agenda item concerns the zoning plan for the Karhunkaataja area in Myllypuro, focusing on balancing sustainable values and nature conservation with the need for housing development. The discussion includes considerations for preserving green spaces and mitigating the impact of construction on the environment.
§4: **Amendment of the Zoning Plan for Pärnunkatu 6 in Vuosaari (No. 12672)** - This agenda item addresses a specific zoning change in Vuosaari, focusing on the balance between increasing housing density and preserving local nature areas. The discussion highlights concerns about the cumulative impact of small-scale development on the environment.
§5: **Initiative by Councillor Coel Thomas on Simultaneous Interpretation at City Council Meetings** - This agenda item discusses a proposal to introduce simultaneous interpretation at City Council meetings to enhance accessibility for non-Finnish and non-Swedish speakers. The discussion covers the costs, practicalities, and potential benefits of such a service.
§6: **Initiative by Councillor Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara to Abandon the Absolute Requirement to Serve Only Vegetarian Food at City Events** - This agenda item concerns a proposal to relax the city's policy of serving only vegetarian food at official events. The discussion includes arguments about freedom of choice, support for local agriculture, and the environmental impact of different food options.
§7: **Social Democratic City Council Group Initiative on Clearing Queues for Non-Urgent Basic Healthcare** - This initiative focuses on addressing the long waiting times for non-urgent primary healthcare in Helsinki. The discussion centers on identifying effective measures to improve access to care, including potential changes to management, organization, and resource allocation.

## Detailed Discussion

### §1: Changes to the 2022 Budget Due to the Corporatization of Helsinki City Transport (HKL)
**Mia Haglund **: Haglund raised concerns about the working conditions of HKL employees following the corporatization. She noted reports in Helsingin Sanomat that many employees had quit due to changes in their collective agreement (KVTES), specifically regarding overtime pay. Haglund requested an update from a member of the Kaupunkiliikenne Oy board regarding these changes and their impact on the company's finances and the city's budget.

### §2: AM-Program 2020 Monitoring Report 2022
**Anni Sinnemäki **: Sinnemäki presented the monitoring report, highlighting the impact of the pandemic on population growth and housing market trends. She noted that population growth had slowed, but housing sales remained strong. Sinnemäki also pointed out challenges in achieving ARA (government-subsidized) housing production targets due to rising construction costs. She emphasized the need to address the backlog of unbuilt ARA housing in future years.
**Otto Meri **: Meri praised the report's finding that rent increases had remained moderate, attributing this to increased housing supply. He opposed efforts to "clear the ARA backlog," arguing that Helsinki needs more owner-occupied housing. Meri inquired about the status of an Aalto University economic analysis of the Hitas system.
**Sinikka Vepsä **: Vepsä defended the Hitas system, arguing that it is necessary to provide affordable homeownership opportunities for Helsinki residents. She criticized investors who buy up small apartments, making it difficult for first-time buyers to enter the market.
**Maria Ohisalo **: Ohisalo thanked everyone involved in efforts to reduce homelessness in Helsinki, emphasizing the importance of the "housing first" principle.
**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Arhinmäki expressed concern that the city is failing to meet its ARA housing production targets, which he said are essential for addressing homelessness. He criticized investors who buy and rent out Hitas apartments, arguing that these apartments should be available to ordinary Helsinki residents.
**Otto Meri **: Meri reiterated his view that increasing housing supply is the best way to reduce housing costs. He argued that Helsinki has enough ARA housing to address homelessness.
**Timo Harakka **: Harakka noted that the slowness of the zoning process is a major challenge for large cities. He suggested that changes to the process for appealing zoning decisions may have inadvertently made the process less efficient.
**Elina Kauppila **: Kauppila argued that ARA housing alone cannot solve homelessness. She announced that she had submitted an initiative to increase supported housing for the homeless.
**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Arhinmäki reiterated that ARA housing is part of the solution to homelessness, but that many homeless people also need supported housing.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma argued that Helsinki needs a variety of tools to provide affordable housing and ensure that low-wage workers can afford to live in the city.
**Otto Meri **: Meri stated that "hokkuspokkus" solutions rarely work and that increasing housing supply is the best way to reduce housing costs.
**Mai Kivelä **: Kivelä emphasized that a key goal of Helsinki's housing policy should be to provide affordable housing for residents. She expressed concern that the city is not meeting its targets for building affordable housing.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma noted that businesses are increasingly concerned about the availability of affordable housing for their employees.
**Risto Rautava **: Rautava defended the NCP's record on housing policy, citing efforts to promote infill development.
**Tuomas Rantanen **: Rantanen pointed out that some rental housing is produced by market forces, while other rental housing is government-subsidized. He emphasized the importance of ensuring that low-wage workers can afford to live in Helsinki.
**Otto Meri **: Meri criticized the "autocratic" nature of the ARA system and argued that the city should focus on increasing housing supply and supporting the housing allowance system.
**Mari Rantanen **: Rantanen criticized the NCP's support for the housing allowance system, arguing that it contributes to high housing costs. She noted that Helsinki has lost population in recent years and that the AM-program should be re-evaluated. Rantanen also called for a study to determine why people are moving out of Helsinki.
**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Arhinmäki criticized the NCP's support for the housing allowance system, arguing that it primarily benefits investors. He defended the construction of affordable housing on a cost-recovery basis.
**Titta Hiltunen **: Hiltunen questioned the NCP's stance on housing policy, noting that the party often supports cuts to housing allowance at the national level.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma argued that the PS opposes both increasing housing production and building affordable housing, which would make it impossible for low-income people to live in Helsinki.
**Eeva Kärkkäinen **: Kärkkäinen questioned the NCP's view that increasing housing allowance spending is a positive thing.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara expressed concern about the decline in population growth in Helsinki.
**Osmo Soininvaara **: Soininvaara argued that the decline in population growth is due to people wanting to live in larger homes. He suggested that affordable housing and housing allowance can be seen as subsidies for employers who pay low wages.
**Otto Meri **: Meri argued that the city lacks data on the revenue lost due to the ARA and Hitas systems. He criticized the Left for not wanting to abolish the housing allowance system, which he said benefits their own members.
**Elina Valtonen **: Valtonen argued that it is better to focus on demand-side subsidies (housing allowance) than supply-side subsidies (ARA housing).
**Mari Rantanen **: Rantanen clarified that the PS opposes high levels of housing construction, but not affordable housing.
**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Arhinmäki stated that the PS's housing policy is to oppose everything. He reiterated his view that the housing allowance system primarily benefits wealthy investors.
**Mia Haglund **: Haglund argued that if the PS gets its way and housing construction in Helsinki stops, the city will become a center for the elite.
**Reetta Vanhanen **: Vanhanen emphasized the importance of affordable housing for attracting workers to Helsinki.
**Jussi Halla-aho **: Halla-aho criticized both the housing allowance system and the claim that increasing housing production will lower housing costs.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara expressed concern that Helsinki is building too many small apartments and that population growth has slowed.
**Mia Haglund **: Haglund reiterated the importance of meeting ARA housing production targets.
**Arja Karhuvaara **: Karhuvaara emphasized the importance of providing services for families in new housing areas. She argued that Helsinki's housing density is too high and that this is driving families to move elsewhere.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara argued that families cannot live in small apartments and that the city needs to build more family-sized apartments.
**Otso Kivekäs **: Kivekäs pointed out that immigrants, students, and the elderly all pay taxes. He noted that population growth in Helsinki has primarily been driven by one- and two-person households.
**Arja Karhuvaara **: Karhuvaara argued that the prices of large family apartments have risen more than the prices of small apartments.
**Timo Harakka **: Harakka noted that the decision to allow students to receive general housing allowance has led to more students living in single-person apartments.
**Laura Korpinen **: Korpinen questioned whether it is wise to provide housing allowance to students who live in their own apartments, even if their parents live in the same city.
**Sinikka Vepsä **: Vepsä argued that elderly people need larger apartments to accommodate their assistive devices. She emphasized the need for affordable housing for healthcare and early childhood education workers.
**Elisa Gebhard **: Gebhard questioned the idea that single-person households are not good taxpayers. She argued that Helsinki needs small apartments to accommodate young people who move to the city for studies.
**Laura Kolehmainen **: Kolehmainen argued that housing policy should not be driven primarily by market logic and that the government has a constitutional obligation to ensure that everyone has access to housing.
**Amanda Pasanen **: Pasanen expressed concern about the affordability of housing for students in Helsinki. She argued that Helsinki is not a densely populated city compared to other European capitals.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara argued that Helsinki is building too many small apartments.
**Sinikka Vepsä **: Vepsä asked whether the city has adequately analyzed the slowdown in population growth. She argued that families are moving out of Helsinki due to high housing costs and a lack of single-family homes.
**Amanda Pasanen **: Pasanen argued that dense apartment construction is necessary to preserve green spaces.
**Otso Kivekäs **: Kivekäs argued that all types of housing production affect the availability of all types of housing. He noted that the increase in rental housing supply has led to a decrease in rental prices.
**Reetta Vanhanen **: Vanhanen emphasized the importance of affordable housing for attracting workers to Helsinki and for addressing the city's personnel shortage.
**Titta Hiltunen **: Hiltunen noted that the decision to allow students to receive general housing allowance was accompanied by a cut to student financial aid. She argued that the city should build more cost-recovery housing.
**Eeva Kärkkäinen **: Kärkkäinen argued that the city should re-evaluate its growth targets in light of the fact that Helsinki is not growing as fast as expected.
**Nina Suomalainen **: Suomalainen emphasized the importance of preserving single-family housing in Helsinki. She questioned whether the city's viherkerroin  is an effective way to increase vegetation.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma noted that the decision to allow students to receive general housing allowance has led to an increase in housing allowance spending.
**Mika Ebeling **: Ebeling proposed a motion to study the reasons for the increased out-migration from Helsinki.
**Anni Sinnemäki **: Sinnemäki stated that two studies on migration patterns and their causes are forthcoming this year. She requested that the proposed motions be withdrawn as the studies will address the issues raised.
**Eva Biaudet **: Biaudet questioned whether the city is being ambitious enough in its use of the viherkerroin .
**Terhi Peltokorpi **: Peltokorpi noted that the AM-program aims to balance housing production with the preservation of green spaces. She emphasized the importance of providing affordable housing for families.
**Sinikka Vepsä **: Vepsä criticized the planning of new housing areas, arguing that services such as early childhood education are often lacking.
**Otto Meri **: Meri criticized the PS's rhetoric about Helsinki becoming "Detroit" and argued that their policies would slow the city's growth. He also criticized those who reject scientific evidence when discussing housing policy.
**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Arhinmäki emphasized that housing policy is an important issue that affects all Helsinki residents. He argued that the city should strive to meet its ARA housing production targets.

### §3: Myllypuro Karhunkaataja Area Zoning Plan and Zoning Change (No. 12550)
**Elina Kauppila **: Kauppila expressed support for the Karhunkaataja zoning plan, but called for greater attention to biodiversity. She proposed a motion to improve the area's ecological connections by building a green bridge, creating meadows, and preserving existing trees.
**Sandra Hagman **: Hagman supported Kauppila's motion.
**Otso Kivekäs **: Kivekäs also supported Kauppila's motion. He noted that while the development will impact some METSO II conservation areas, it is important to consider the broader impact of housing construction on biodiversity.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma noted that the Karhunkaataja area is one of the first major infill development projects to move forward after the adoption of the city's general plan. She acknowledged concerns from local residents about the impact of the development on traffic.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara stated that residents are generally "furious" about infill development.
**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Heinäluoma responded that residents of Myllypuro have generally been supportive of the Karhunkaataja development.
**Mari Rantanen **: Rantanen argued that the city's high housing construction targets are incompatible with preserving green spaces.
**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Asko-Seljavaara clarified that residents in Lauttasaari and Vuosaari are "furious" about infill development.
**Laura Korpinen **: Korpinen argued that the city's talk about carbon neutrality and biodiversity is just "empty words."
**Eeva Kärkkäinen **: Kärkkäinen emphasized the importance of resident participation in planning decisions.

# Helsingin Kaupunginvaltuuston Kokouspöytäkirja 18.5.2022

## Esityslistan Yleiskatsaus
§107: Helsingin Kaupungin Liikenneliikelaitoksen Toiminnanyhtiöittämisen Aiheuttamat Muutokset Vuoden 2022 Talousarvioon - Käsittelyssä tekninen päätös, jossa huomioidaan Kaupunkiliikenne Oy:n yhtiöittämisen vaikutukset työntekijöiden olosuhteisiin ja talouteen. Valtuutettu Haglund pyysi päivitystä työntekijöiden olosuhteiden muutoksista.
§108: AM-Ohjelman 2020 Seurantaraportti 2022 - Käsiteltiin asumisen ja maankäytön ohjelman seurantaraporttia, jossa asetetaan tavoitteita asuntotuotannolle ja kaavoitukselle. Apulaispormestari Sinnemäki avasi raporttia ja valtuutetut kommentoivat asunnottomuutta, ARA-tuotantoa ja Hitas-järjestelmää.
§112: Myllypuron Karhunkatajan Alueen Asemakaava ja Asemakaavan Muutos (Nro 12550) - Käsittelyssä Karhunkatajan kaava, jossa huomioidaan kestäviä arvoja. Valtuutettu Kauppila esitti ponsiehdotuksen luonnon monimuotoisuuden huomioimiseksi.
§113: Vuosaaren Pärnunkatu 6:n Asemakaavan Muuttaminen (Nro 12672) - Käsittelyssä Pärnunkadun asemakaavan muutos. Valtuutettu Huff toi esille huolen luontoalueiden vähenemisestä Vuosaaressa.

§115: Valtuutettu Coel Thomasin Aloite Simultaanitulkauksesta Kaupunginvaltuuston Kokouksissa - Käsittelyssä valtuutettu Thomasin aloite simultaanitulkkauksesta. Valtuutettu Miettinen esitti ponnen kokemusten vertailusta muissa kunnissa.
§116: Valtuutettu Sirpa Asko-Seljavaaran Aloite Luopumiseksi Ehdottomasta Määräyksestä Tarjoilla Vain Kasvisruokia Kaupungin Tilaisuuksissa - Käsittelyssä valtuutettu Asko-Seljavaaran aloite kasvisruokamääräyksen pehmentämiseksi. # Helsinki City Council Meeting Minutes from April 27, 2022

## Agenda Overview
§96: **Question Time, Item 3.1: Mari Rantanen – Child Protection Notification Processes in Helsinki After 2012** - Councillor Rantanen inquired about the measures Helsinki has taken since 2012 to prevent child homicides, referencing a recent case with similarities to the 2012 Vilja Eerika case. She questioned the systematic processes in place for repeated child protection notifications and the independence of internal reviews.

§96: **Question Time, Item 3.3: Johanna Nuorteva – Labor Shortage in Early Childhood Education, Social Services, and Healthcare** - Councillor Nuorteva raised concerns about the severe labor shortage in essential services, particularly in early childhood education, social services, and healthcare. She inquired about the progress of measures to improve staff availability, the impact of solutions on daily life in kindergartens, and how staff have been involved in developing solutions to improve well-being and attractiveness.

§96: **Question Time, Item 3.2: Laura Kolbe – Revitalizing Urban Culture and Senate Square** - Councillor Kolbe questioned the city's plans to restore Senate Square's status as a premier event space and attractive urban oasis, noting its underutilization and the slow progress of lighting renovations. She suggested collaboration with various stakeholders and drawing inspiration from other capital cities.

§99: **Item 6: Approval of the HUS Group's Articles of Association** - The council discussed and voted on approving the articles of association for the new HUS Group, a healthcare consortium formed as part of the Uusimaa regional solution within the broader social and healthcare reform. The agreement outlines the structure, governance, and financial arrangements for specialized healthcare services in the region.

§102: **Item 9: Councillor Mari Holopainen's Initiative on Establishing a Night-Time District or Blocks** - The council discussed an initiative to establish a designated night-time district or blocks in Helsinki to promote nightlife and cultural activities while minimizing disturbance to residents. The discussion covered potential locations, noise concerns, and the role of the city in facilitating such initiatives.

## Detailed Discussion

### §96: Question Time, Item 3.1: Mari Rantanen – Child Protection Notification Processes in Helsinki After 2012

**Mari Rantanen **: Raised concerns about a recent child homicide case and its similarities to the 2012 Vilja Eerika case. She asked what actions Helsinki has taken since 2012 to prevent such tragedies and how the city could improve its child protection measures. She also questioned whether there was a systematic process to ensure that repeated notifications about a child are handled with a comprehensive overview and suggested an independent review of the city's processes.

**Daniel Sazonov **: Acknowledged the tragic nature of the case and stated that a thorough investigation is necessary before determining if the incident could have been prevented. He outlined several changes made in child protection over the past decade, including legislative changes requiring mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse, immediate processing of child protection notifications, and increased personal contact with children in the system. He also noted a significant decrease in the caseload of child protection social workers.

**Mari Rantanen **: Asked for clarification on whether there is a systematic process to ensure that repeated notifications about a child are handled with a comprehensive overview, rather than being dispersed among different workers. She also questioned the independence of internal reviews of child protection actions, suggesting an external review might be beneficial.

**Johanna Nuorteva **: Emphasized the importance of collaboration between schools and child protection services, noting that teachers often observe children in distress but their input is not always adequately considered in placement decisions. She advocated for stronger cooperation and greater consideration of the perspectives of professionals who work with children daily.

**Eva Biaudet **: Highlighted the importance of professionals in schools, healthcare centers, and the police being able to identify when children are at risk. She questioned whether there is sufficient support for children and whether inquiries about children's well-being are systematically made in healthcare settings, particularly when parents have mental health issues.

**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Stressed the responsibility of everyone to report suspected child abuse. She mentioned that doctors are instructed to report suspected abuse to the police if a child presents with injuries that suggest parental involvement.

**Veronika Honkasalo **: Noted that the pattern in such cases often involves neighborhood concerns and multiple home visits by professionals, but a failure to recognize the severity of the situation before it is too late. She asked how a child-specific perspective is currently incorporated into substance abuse and mental health services, even when no formal child protection notifications have been made.

**Mika Ebeling **: Questioned whether there is a conflict between data protection and the need for information sharing to prevent tragedies. He asked if data protection regulations are hindering the flow of critical information and whether legislative changes are needed.

**Pentti Arajärvi **: Emphasized the importance of child protection and the mandatory reporting obligation. He supported Honkasalo's point about checking on children when adults have problems, and added that the reverse is also important: checking on parents when children need child protection.

**Daniel Sazonov **: Responded that each child has a designated social worker responsible for handling notifications related to that child, which helps to build a comprehensive picture of the situation. He acknowledged that the system is not perfect and that there is a need to continuously strengthen cooperation between different authorities and professionals. He also addressed the data protection issue, stating that it is an ongoing national discussion and that the government is working to improve information flow while balancing privacy concerns.

### §96: Question Time, Item 3.3: Johanna Nuorteva – Labor Shortage in Early Childhood Education, Social Services, and Healthcare

**Johanna Nuorteva **: Inquired about the progress of measures to address the labor shortage in essential services, including the implementation of a salary development program. She asked how the solutions have impacted daily life in kindergartens and how staff have been involved in developing solutions to improve well-being and attractiveness. She also asked about acute solutions planned for the summer holiday period.

**Juhana Vartiainen **: Outlined the city's strategy to address the labor shortage, including a workforce availability project to open new recruitment channels, advocacy efforts, and strengthened coordination. He mentioned a salary development program with a budget of five million euros, which aims to increase the city's attractiveness as an employer and raise salaries in professions facing recruitment challenges. He noted that discussions on the program's priorities will take place after new collective bargaining agreements are reached.

**Nasima Razmyar **: Detailed budget allocations and measures taken to support staff availability in early childhood education, including funding for substitute arrangements, a rapid assistance unit, streamlined recruitment processes, and incentive bonuses for new teachers and childcare workers. She highlighted the importance of induction programs and the establishment of an availability team to develop and enhance measures to improve staff retention and attraction. She also mentioned the coordination group for promoting the availability of early childhood education personnel, which she chairs.

**Johanna Nuorteva **: Emphasized the importance of involving grassroots-level employees in decision-making and gathering their ideas for improving well-being and retention. She reiterated her concern about the summer staffing situation and asked if there are any acute solutions planned for all sectors facing labor shortages to ensure essential services are maintained during the holiday period.

**Anniina Iskanius **: Stressed the need for conversion training and investments in salaries in the early childhood education sector. She asked about the progress and timeline of proposals from the early childhood education task force established during Mayor Vapaavuori's term.

**Reetta Vanhanen **: Emphasized the importance of solving the labor shortage to deliver on the city's service promise. She hoped that the actions of the early childhood education working group would soon be visible in kindergartens. She also raised concerns about difficulties in recruiting summer substitutes in home care and asked about acute solutions for the summer substitute situation.

**Teija Makkonen **: Stated that the poor staffing situation and working conditions in early childhood education affect all client families and especially children. She claimed that there is a shortage of early childhood education places in Northeast Helsinki and questioned the accuracy of population forecasts.

**Nora Grotenfelt **: Asked how the city could better support private service providers in early childhood education, given that several have ceased operations. She also asked about measures taken to secure permission for the City of Helsinki to organize basic vocational education in the field of education and guidance.

**Petra Malin **: Highlighted the importance of the salary program and addressing working conditions to solve the labor shortage. She asked if there are plans to conduct broad consultations with employees in other sectors facing labor shortages, similar to what was done in early childhood education.

**Sinikka Vepsä **: Suggested increasing apprenticeship training places and exploring the recruitment of foreign healthcare professionals. She also raised concerns about pay disparities between Seure employees and those hired through private recruitment firms.

**Sari Sarkomaa **: Emphasized the importance of securing the retention and attraction of skilled workers in the well-being services sector. She asked how the city could engage in discussions with the national government to secure its involvement in addressing the issue, as the national government had promised to look into the matter.

**Juhana Vartiainen **: Acknowledged that the labor shortage is a national problem and that measures are needed at the national level to increase the labor supply. He stated that the government has taken some commendable actions, such as introducing a proposal to abolish the unemployment trap. He also noted that other Nordic countries are ahead of Finland in addressing labor availability and salary issues in the public sector. He suggested focusing on good management, personnel policies, and local solutions, and allocating resources generated from productivity improvements to salaries in sectors facing availability problems.

**Nasima Razmyar **: Agreed that the situation has developed over a long period and cannot be solved quickly. She emphasized the importance of both short-term and long-term solutions, such as increasing training opportunities. She also mentioned the increased private care allowance. She stated that the number of children on holiday during the summer usually means that the staffing situation is not a significant issue. She emphasized the importance of listening to staff and encouraging them in their work.

### §96: Question Time, Item 3.2: Laura Kolbe – Revitalizing Urban Culture and Senate Square

**Laura Kolbe **: Noted that Senate Square has lost its role as Helsinki's most important event square and inquired about measures to restore its status as a premier event space and attractive urban oasis. She suggested collaboration with various stakeholders and drawing inspiration from other capital cities.

**Anni Sinnemäki **: Announced that electricity will be restored to the ice cream kiosk on May 16, enabling ice cream sales. She explained that the ongoing lighting renovation, which includes archaeological excavations, is expected to be completed in the fall. She stated that the new lighting will emphasize the architectural ensemble around the square. She mentioned upcoming events on Senate Square, including Tuomaan Markkinat, Suursitsit, a side event of Hamina Tattoo, and the Helsinki Festival. She suggested that the city's event unit could collaborate with the stakeholders mentioned by Kolbe to plan future activities on Senate Square.

**Laura Kolbe **: Thanked Sinnemäki for the response and highlighted the unfortunate duration of the lighting project. She suggested that a "Senate Square host" could oversee the square's maintenance and that more could be done to make the square attractive in winter. She also suggested classical music events and a classical music theme for New Year's celebrations.

**Björn Månsson **: Agreed that Senate Square is Helsinki's heart and a central logistical point. He supported the idea of a summer terrace and suggested that it should have a permanent location on Senate Square. He also supported the idea of illuminating the buildings around the square year-round.

**Sami Muttilainen **: Expressed less concern about Senate Square and suggested focusing on Sitratori or Malmintori. He questioned what interesting events have taken place on Senate Square in recent memory and suggested that it could be used for late-night events, referencing the initiative on a night-time district. He also inquired about the location of the Hietsu flea market.

**Matias Pajula **: Agreed with Kolbe on the importance of collaboration with city residents to find better ways to utilize Senate Square. He also emphasized the importance of improving other squares and public spaces throughout Helsinki, not just in the city center. He asked how the city plans to ensure that other squares and public spaces are better utilized.

**Otso Kivekäs **: Asked whether the practice of using the edges of Senate Square as a parking area for tourist buses could be discontinued to improve the square's ambiance and promote tourism.

**Pilvi Torsti **: Suggested that it should not be difficult to find natural uses for Senate Square, given its association with the church, the state, and the university. She noted that 6,000 people gathered on Senate Square on Easter Monday to support Ukraine, highlighting its suitability for such events.

**Jenni Pajunen **: Supported adding more life to Senate Square and suggested looking to other capital cities for inspiration. She hoped that tourists could be attracted back to Helsinki but that Senate Square would not be returned to a tourist bus parking lot. She also asked about the planning progress for the upcoming summer terrace in Hietsu.

**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Raised concerns about the availability of open, public urban space that does not require rental fees. She expressed concern that urban densification is reducing the amount of such space and that it is increasingly being replaced by commercial spaces.

**Anni Sinnemäki **: Mentioned the establishment of a new company, Kaupunkitilat Oy, to revitalize public spaces throughout the city. She noted that the city has invested significantly in summer terraces and that a commercially sustainable concept is needed for the future. She stated that the cost of organizing events on Senate Square is high due to the lack of infrastructure. She concluded by mentioning the Ukraine demonstration as an example of the power of human presence on Senate Square.

### §99: Item 6: Approval of the HUS Group's Articles of Association

**Daniel Sazonov **: Introduced the item, explaining that the Uusimaa regional solution within the social and healthcare reform requires the organization of specialized healthcare through a new HUS Group. He stated that legislation mandates the establishment of the HUS Group by the welfare regions and Helsinki, with a deadline of the end of April. He outlined the preparation process, which involved a working group and a political monitoring group with representatives from each region and Helsinki. He emphasized that the proposed articles of association reflect the outcome of political negotiations and aim to secure a political majority in each region. He highlighted the key changes related to the choice of a general assembly (yhtymäkokous) over a council (yhtymävaltuusto) as the governing body, balanced by a politically representative board. He also outlined the HUS Group's tasks and the shift to a framework budgeting system with usage-based equalization.

**Pentti Arajärvi **: Acknowledged the thorough preparation and balanced nature of the articles of association. However, he raised concerns about the lack of democratic oversight and public discourse in the new system, particularly regarding specialized healthcare in Uusimaa. He argued that the absence of a publicly accessible council diminishes citizen participation and influence. He proposed returning the articles of association for further preparation to include a proposal for a HUS Group council.

**Otso Kivekäs **: Argued against the return proposal, stating that all other Uusimaa regions have already approved the articles of association. He warned that rejecting the agreement would not lead to the preparation of a council model but would instead result in the state imposing a model that is unlikely to be favorable.

**Pentti Arajärvi **: Questioned the democratic nature of a process where the council can only approve or reject the proposal, without the possibility of amendment. He stated that he had never seen a draft agreement that even theoretically considered a council model.

**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Stated that the SDP group has consistently supported a council model and that their position has been communicated to other political groups. She argued that it is important to maintain this position, even in the face of deadlines.

**Otso Kivekäs **: Argued that the process has been democratic through representative democracy, with elected officials participating in the preparation and negotiation of the agreement. He stated that the goal should be to achieve a good outcome, not just to express a position.

**Pentti Arajärvi **: Reiterated that if an issue is important and principled, such as the possibility of public discourse, it is justifiable to maintain that position to the bitter end.

**Anna Vuorjoki **: Argued that representative democracy includes active citizen discussion between elections. She stated that the HUS Group council model would eliminate a forum for public discussion and that the public has a right to hear the discussion about the substantive issues, not just the process.

**Otso Kivekäs **: Clarified that the central forum for political public discussion is the city council, which provides the mandate and guidelines for the HUS Group assembly.

**Reetta Vanhanen **: Emphasized the importance of moving forward with the HUS Group agreement to implement the social and healthcare reform. She stated that the HUS Group board will have broad political representation and that the instructions for the assembly representatives will be decided politically in the city government. She argued that the agreement represents a Uusimaa-wide consensus and that rejecting it would cede decision-making power to the state.

**Björn Månsson **: Stated that the Swedish People's Party preferred to retain a representative council as the highest decision-making body in HUS, but they were in the minority. He noted that the five individuals with the highest decision-making power will be guided by the regional councils and governments. He emphasized the importance of the HUS Group board and the retention of university representatives.

**Mari Rantanen **: Argued that the weak point of the agreement is the choice of an assembly over a council. She stated that one of the key arguments used by government parties during the social and healthcare reform was that it would increase democracy. She argued that the agreement concentrates power in too few hands and that small parties will not have the opportunity to gain representation.

**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Responded to Rantanen's comments, stating that the SDP has consistently advocated for a council model and that it is disingenuous to argue that it is too late to consider it.

**Jenni Pajunen **: Stated that the new HUS Group must be able to shorten queues and improve staff working conditions and well-being. She emphasized the importance of ensuring funding for cutting-edge research. She argued that returning the agreement for preparation would shift decision-making from the city to the state.

**Anna Vuorjoki **: Argued that specialized healthcare is a matter of life and death and that the decisions made about prioritization and organization are significant value choices. She stated that the HUS Group is not just a producer but also has independent responsibility for organizing services. She argued that the assembly model does not promote democracy and transparency in the best possible way, as it would involve a small group of politicians with expertise in HUS matters and would eliminate a forum for public discussion.

**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Stated that she does not support the return proposal and approves the city government's proposal. She stated that everything depends on money and how much the state will allocate to HUS operations.

**Sanna Vesikansa **: Stated that she does not support the return proposal. She stated that Helsinki will have a single binding budget from the state that must cover both specialized healthcare and basic services. She emphasized the importance of good cooperation and that the service strategy should be discussed in the council.

**Seija Muurinen **: Stated that she does not support the return proposal. She stated that the proposal for the HUS Group's articles of association is a suitably broad and important package for securing the region's residents' healthcare services. She stated that the owner control was strongly emphasized in the proposal.

**Risto Rautava **: Stated that he does not support the return of the matter. He stated that the HUS-consortium's council has not necessarily increased democracy or opportunities for discussion.

**Eveliina Heinäluoma **: Stated that she supports the return of the matter. She stated that the SDP's council group has been consistent throughout the process. She stated that the HSL and public transport matters are in a slightly different position compared to the very important funding of social and health services.

**Daniel Sazonov **: Stated that all materials and documents are public. He stated that the official representation operates through public operating instructions, which are decided in the regions' and Helsinki's bodies. He stated that it is even more democratic that representatives of six political groups participate in the city government.

**Reetta Vanhanen **: Stated that the social democrats have indeed presented positions throughout the process, and in Uusimaa and Helsinki they have represented different positions among themselves regarding the decision-making structure of HUS.

**Tuomas Rantanen **: Stated that he does not support the return, which is strange shadow boxing. He stated that the compromise that is here for us to decide, we either accept it or not.

**Osmo Soininvaara **: Stated that all models in which making a decision requires the same decision from several councils are completely undemocratic.

**Pentti Arajärvi **: Stated that the problem is, of course, that all people must be treated and cared for.

**Anna Vuorjoki **: Stated that the HUS-council's resources are not enough to handle them properly.

**Sirpa Asko-Seljavaara **: Stated that she still does not support the return, because a politician does not order anything, how patients are treated and does not know anything about diseases.

### §102: Item 9: Councillor Mari Holopainen's Initiative on Establishing a Night-Time District or Blocks

**Sami Muttilainen **: Thanked the initiator and stated that a night-time district is a very good idea and could be put into practice. He stated that the city is constantly growing, and it seems that the space here is constantly decreasing, so commercial and non-commercial actors can make a living and have fun here. He stated that the city is constantly counting the votes that oppose general comfort. He stated that the city's guidelines are twisted every year, until when the terraces can be open and until when live music can be played here. He stated that this is not in line with the line of any European capital. He suggested Roihupelto and Vallila as areas that could be developed as night-time districts. He asked what is happening with the night pilot today.

**Jussi Halla-aho **: Stated that the answer to the initiative that the city government approved is substantively very good. He stated that it is a bit surprising that when this answer first justifies very well what problems are related to the implementation or promotion of this initiative, then it comes to the conclusion that this is a commendable idea. He stated that he is a little afraid that if a positive view is taken on the proposal made in the initiative, this will later become an open check for the implementation of various projects that cause costs and other problems. He stated that there is no need for such a night-time district or block. He stated that the general noise is a disturbing factor for the residents of hotels, for example. For this reason, he proposes returning the matter for preparation so that the above is taken into account.

**Sami Muttilainen **: Stated that there is Roihupelto or Vallila, where there is no hotel business, for example. He stated that there are already creative elements in a way, that this matter can only be developed more. He stated that it is a pity that this matter cannot be planned together.

**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Stated that reconciling nightlife and events with other city life and housing is not just a problem for Helsinki, but for all large and slightly smaller cities. He stated that it is a big question where to find spaces for events, outdoor events that are not disruptive. He stated that this is a question that is being considered in all European cities.

**Arja Karhuvaara **: Stated that she does not support any increase in night noise, because those who are weaker at promoting their own affairs suffer the most from the so-called entertainment.

**Oona Hagman **: Stated that she does not support the return proposal in any way. She stated that Councillor Holopainen's initiative to establish and develop a night-time district in the City of Helsinki is a great way to liven up the city. She suggested that Hanasaari, when it becomes available, whether in 2023 or later, would be a great place and area for this type of activity.

**Johanna Nuorteva **: Stated that the initiative to promote night-time districts and night-time blocks is good. She stated that it is important that Helsinki offers a platform for various actors, the city's own activities and the organization of events.

**Mika Ebeling **: Stated that he approves that people are allowed to frolic at night, as long as they do not disturb others. He stated that not getting enough sleep and at the right time has significant health disadvantages. He stated that since sleep deprivation accelerates brain degeneration, he does not see it as socially appropriate to be enthusiastic about this matter.

**Mia Haglund **: Stated that she does not support the return proposal made. She stated that she sees the Vallila industrial area as a great place to try out the ideas and directions brought up by the initiative.

**Teija Makkonen **: Stated that she supports Councillor Halla-aho's return.

**Sami Muttilainen **: Stated that these speeches mainly disturb people who work at night. He stated that it sounds from many mouths that if you were working in night radio or in a hospital or anywhere, it might be the wrong career choice or almost threatened.

**Paavo Arhinmäki **: Stated that the task of the night pilot was a temporary task in the city office, and when the fixed term ended, this was not continued.

**Mika Raatikainen **: Stated that he supports the return proposal made. He stated that there is already a night-time district. He stated that he lives there, its name is Kontula.

**Tuomas Rantanen **: Stated that he does not support the return. He stated that the block where we are now, the market blocks, could be one where, for example, the opening hours of restaurants would be later, when tourists and others would easily find it.

**Laura Korpinen **: Stated that she supports the return absolutely.

**Laura Kolbe **: Stated that she does not support the return. She stated that the city can enable people who need to experience the urban environment at different times of the year and day, so that it is possible.

**Jussi Halla-aho **: Stated that the restaurant opening hours are based on legislation.

**Hilkka Ahde **: Stated that she does not support the return.

**Amanda Pasanen **: Stated that she is of the opinion that there must be life in the city. She stated that the point of the night-time district is that the nightlife is planned and made possible in an area where it does not disturb sleeping people.

**Oona Hagman **: Stated that she does not support the return.

**Sami Muttilainen **: Stated that he would like to have a pont related to the night pilot.

**Nina Miettinen **: Stated that it would be good to consider whether the archipelago could also be divided into quiet islands and those where you could more freely play music later into the night.

**Elina Kauppila **: Stated that she also thinks the night-time district idea is very good.

**Arja Karhuvaara **: Stated that she also agrees to the night life in the city of Helsinki, if the ethical principles of the scouts are followed.
